p: Although bees are now widely acknowledged as key pollinators of wild and cultivated plants, as well as important income sources for beekeepers around the globe (Potts et al., 2016), the joint impact of habitat degradation and climate change is currently threatening their wild populations (Brown & Paxton, 2009; Hadley & Betts, 2011; Potts et al., 2010; Viana et al., 2012; Wratten, Gillespie, Decourtye, Mader, & Desneux, 2012). Habitat loss has been related to reductions in native bee abundance and richness (Kennedy et al., 2013), whereas land use changes have fragmented populations in some species (Jha, 2015; Jha & Kremen, 2013). Additionally, climate change is expected to modify the availability of floral and nesting resources and affect bee physiology, thereby resulting in distribution range shifts and reductions in many species (Faleiro, Nem√©sio, & Loyola, 2018; Giannini et al., 2017; Kerr et al., 2015; Le Conte & Navajas, 2008; Pyke, Thomson, Inouye, & Miller, 2016; Willmer, 2014).
